newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft sees development without Citrix.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft sees development without Citrix.

text.p: A Microsoft Corp product team is working on integrating a multi-user capability into its Windows NT server software, now offered by Citrix Systems Inc, Senior Vice President Jim Allchin said on Thursday.

"We have a development team under way," Allchin said in a phone interview. "Today, we have no plans other than to build it ourselves," he said when asked about Citrix's statement on Wednesday that Microsoft was looking at licensing certain Citrix technologies. Allchin said Microsoft is "always talking" to other companies about licensing technology. But, he emphasized, "Today, we are on our own path."

Allchin said Microsoft already had a team of "reasonable" size working on developing multi-user capability, which would allow, with remote access, users on multiple devices to access a server running Windows NT and applications.

"We always have people working on future technologies," said Allchin, who is senior vice president of personal and business systems at Microsoft. "We have determined that we are going to complete this and make it available."
Allchin declined to say how long Microsoft had been developing the software or when the capability would become available.
"Citrix and Microsoft have a partnership today," Allchin said. "It's complete speculation to talk about what might happen in the future."
Late Wednesday, Citrix said that as part of cross-licensing talks, Microsoft informed Citrix that it may develop the multi-user capability for Windows NT internally, or look to other companies.

"Because of a contractual agreement with Citrix, we have to tell them that we are going to do this," Allchin said. "Customers are asking for this....It's a natural extension of the family that we already have."
"It should not be a surprise to anyone. It's just another part of the Windows family," Allchin said.
Last year, for example, Microsoft introduced Windows CE, a slimmed-down version of Windows, and Windows applications for personal digital assistants.
Allchin said Microsoft was talking to other companies in addition to Citrix but declined to give any further details.
"We talk to people all the time. There is nothing of consequence to be said today," he said. "We have a team doing it (the development) and we would consider other technology if it accelerates it."
